title: Orchard planted by previous owner
vignette: A farmer buys an orchard that was planted by someone else before the first harvest. A local tradition requires donating a farm’s inaugural yield. Is he obliged to donate from this orchard?

options.text: Yes; as the current owner, he bears the obligation.
No; since he didn’t plant it, its first yield is exempt.

title: Orchard sold and reacquired
vignette: A farmer plants an orchard then sells it to a corporate buyer, but later repurchases it before harvest. Does the tradition to donate first yield apply?

options.text: Yes; final ownership restores the obligation.
No; the interim non-farmer ownership disqualifies it.

title: Tenant vs. landowner obligation
vignette: A tenant cultivates an orchard on land owned by someone else. Who must donate the inaugural harvest to the community?

options.text: Tenant; he did the work and harvested the fruit.

title: Co-owned orchard
vignette: An orchard is co-owned by a private farmer and an outside investor. Does its first harvest qualify for the donation tradition?

options.text: No; any non-farmer stake disqualifies the produce.

title: Returnee’s pledge wording
vignette: At the annual harvest festival, participants recite a standard pledge about “joining our founding community.” A longtime expatriate returns and takes part. Should they use the standard wording or a modified version acknowledging their return?

options.text: Standard wording; emphasize unity with the group.
Modified wording; reflect their personal journey.

title: New member’s declaration
vignette: During the festival procession, newcomers make a declaration of belonging. Must a recent recruit use a unique statement about their individual conversion, or the same communal declaration as everyone else?

title: Quarantined donor leaving gift
vignette: A person under a temporary quarantine brings a donation crate to an event venue but cannot enter due to health rules. May they leave the crate at the entrance and depart?

options.text: Yes; leaving the crate fulfills the obligation.
No; health restrictions invalidate the donation.

title: Non-verbal consent at ceremony
vignette: Attendees must verbally declare their intent to participate in the festival. A deaf-mute individual cannot speak. Can they use gestures to fulfill the declaration requirement?

options.text: Yes; gestures convey the required intent.

title: Double marking of inaugural produce
vignette: A farmer marks his first-harvest fruits with a ribbon in the field to signal they’re inaugural. After picking, must he mark them again to confirm his intent?

options.text: Yes; both field-marking and post-harvest marking are required.
